meta.name: AURA Question Bank
meta.description: Comprehensive dating compatibility questions optimized for OKCupid-style matching

questions.text: Have you ever been in a physical fight with a romantic partner?

options.text: Once, and I deeply regret it

metadata.explanation: Physical violence is a hard dealbreaker for most

questions.text: Have you ever sent unsolicited sexual images to someone?

options.text: Once when I was young and regret it
Only when I thought they'd want it
I don't see the problem with it

questions.text: When someone isn't responding to your texts, you typically:

options.text: Wait patiently - they'll respond when they can
Send a follow-up after a day or so
Send multiple messages to make sure they saw it
Try calling or reaching out other ways
Get increasingly upset until they respond

questions.text: How many of your exes would say the breakup was primarily your fault?

options.text: All of them, but they're all wrong

questions.text: How would you describe most of your past relationships?

options.text: Mostly difficult but I've grown from them
I prefer not to think about them

metadata.explanation: Blaming all exes indicates pattern of deflection

questions.text: When you get really angry, you usually:

options.text: Take space to calm down before discussing
Express it verbally but stay respectful
Raise your voice but don't say anything cruel

metadata.explanation: Physical expressions of anger predict violence

questions.text: How do you feel about your partner having close friends of the gender they're attracted to?

options.text: Fine, but I'd want to meet them
A bit uncomfortable but I'd manage

questions.text: How often do you drink to the point of intoxication?
How often do you use recreational drugs?

metadata.explanation: Lifestyle compatibility - not inherently red flag

questions.text: How often do you watch pornography?

metadata.explanation: High frequency may indicate addiction or impact intimacy

questions.text: Have you ever cheated on a partner?

options.text: Once, and I learned from it
I don't consider it cheating if they don't find out

metadata.explanation: Pattern of infidelity predicts future behavior

questions.text: If you found yourself attracted to someone while in a relationship, you would:

options.text: Acknowledge it internally and recommit to my partner
Talk to my partner about it
See where it goes - feelings happen
Act on it if I thought I wouldn't get caught

questions.text: Have you ever hidden significant debt or financial problems from a partner?

options.text: What they don't know won't hurt them

questions.text: Have you ever been arrested?

options.text: Yes, for something minor (traffic, protest, etc.)

questions.text: Have you ever shown up unannounced at someone's home or workplace to 'check on them'?

options.text: Once to surprise a partner (positively received)
Yes, because I was worried about them
Yes, to see if they were lying about where they were

questions.text: Have you ever gone through a partner's phone or email without permission?

options.text: Once, and felt terrible about it
Yes, when I had reason to suspect something
Yes, regularly - partners shouldn't have secrets

questions.text: How do you feel when your partner mentions an ex?

options.text: Fine - the past is the past
Very uncomfortable - I'd rather not hear about them
Angry - why are they thinking about their ex?

questions.text: If your partner isn't in the mood for sex, you typically:

options.text: Accept it completely - consent is essential
Accept it but might feel a bit disappointed
Try to get them in the mood

questions.text: When you want something from a partner, you:

options.text: Ask directly and accept their answer
Explain why it matters to you
Find the right moment and approach
Use subtle hints until they figure it out
Find ways to make them want to give it to you

questions.text: Have you ever intentionally said something to make a partner feel insecure?

options.text: Yes, in heated moments I regret
Yes, when they needed a reality check
Yes, to keep them invested in the relationship

questions.text: When a partner remembers an event differently than you do, you:

options.text: Consider that you might be wrong
Trust your memory but stay open
Help them understand what actually happened

questions.text: How do you feel about your partner spending time with their friends without you?

options.text: Great - we both need our own social lives
Fine, as long as it's not too frequent
A bit left out - I'd prefer to join
Uncomfortable - what are they doing without me?

questions.text: In a serious relationship, how should finances work?

options.text: Completely separate - each person manages their own
Mostly separate with some shared expenses
Joint for shared expenses, separate for personal
One person should manage all the money

questions.text: Have you ever been to therapy or counseling?

options.text: Yes, in the past - found it helpful
Yes, tried it but it wasn't for me
No, but I'm open to it
No, I don't believe in therapy

questions.text: When you've hurt a partner's feelings, you typically:

options.text: Apologize sincerely and work to change
Explain why they shouldn't feel that way
Point out what they did to deserve it

questions.text: In conflicts, do you usually feel like the victim?

options.text: Rarely - I try to see my part in things
Often - I seem to attract difficult people
Usually - people take advantage of me
Always - the world is against me

questions.text: When your partner is upset about something unrelated to you, you:

options.text: Try to help solve the problem
Give them space until they feel better
Wonder why they're making it your problem

questions.text: During an argument, how long might you go without speaking to your partner?

options.text: A few minutes to cool down
A day if it's really bad
As long as it takes for them to apologize

metadata.explanation: Stonewalling is one of Gottman's 'Four Horsemen'

questions.text: Have you ever threatened to leave a relationship to get what you wanted?

options.text: Once, and it was a genuine consideration
A few times when things were really bad
Yes, it's an effective way to get attention
Yes, if they don't meet my needs they should know the stakes

questions.text: Have you ever threatened to harm yourself to prevent a partner from leaving?

options.text: No, but I've expressed genuine distress
Once, in a moment of crisis
Yes, it's the only way to make them understand

questions.text: Do you own any firearms?

metadata.explanation: Lifestyle compatibility - not inherently red flag

questions.text: How would you describe your driving?

options.text: I drive fast and take risks

questions.text: How often do you gamble?

options.text: Rarely (a few times a year for fun)

questions.text: How would you describe your current debt situation (excluding mortgage)?

options.text: Moderate debt with a payoff plan

questions.text: What is your current employment situation?
How often do you tell 'white lies' to your partner?

options.text: Rarely - only to spare feelings on trivial things
Often - it's easier than the truth
Regularly - they don't need to know everything

questions.text: When your partner makes a mistake, you typically:

options.text: Help them fix it without judgment
Make sure they know about it

questions.text: When a partner says 'no' to something you want, you:

options.text: Keep bringing it up until they reconsider

questions.text: How would your partner feel about your social media behavior?

options.text: There are things I keep private
I have accounts they don't know about
They'd be upset if they saw everything

questions.text: What would your closest friends say is your biggest relationship flaw?
Have you ever created fake profiles or catfished someone?

options.text: Once as a teenager, regret it
Yes, to see if a partner was cheating

questions.text: During intimacy, when is it okay to try something new?

options.text: Only after discussing and getting explicit agreement
When you're fairly sure they'd be into it
Surprise them and see how they react
Whenever you want - easier to ask forgiveness

questions.text: Have you ever dated or had relations with a work colleague while in a relationship?

options.text: What happens at work stays at work

questions.text: How often do you lose your temper?
Has a partner ever accused you of being abusive, controlling, or toxic?

options.text: Once, and I took it seriously
Yes, multiple partners have said this
Yes, but they were the abusive ones

metadata.explanation: Pattern of abuse accusations - serious indicator

questions.text: Has anyone ever filed a restraining order against you?

options.text: One was filed but not granted

questions.text: What are you looking for on this app?
What's the longest relationship you've been in?

options.text: I haven't been in a relationship

questions.text: If your partner wasn't ready to say 'I love you' yet, you would:

options.text: Express your feelings anyway and give them time
Ask when they think they might be ready
Feel hurt and question the relationship
Consider ending things - they should know by now

questions.text: Do you have close friends or family you confide in?

options.text: Not really - I keep to myself

questions.text: Workers should have the right to unionize
Billionaires:

options.text: Should not exist - no ethical way to accumulate that much
Should be taxed heavily to fund public services
Earned their wealth and deserve to keep most of it
Are job creators and benefit society
Are proof that hard work pays off

questions.text: A pregnant person's right to abortion:

options.text: Is absolute and should have no legal restrictions
Should be protected with few restrictions
Should not exist except for life-threatening situations

metadata.explanation: Fundamental values alignment on bodily autonomy

questions.text: When workers strike:

options.text: I always support them - workers deserve better
They should be fired and replaced

questions.text: Healthcare should be:

options.text: Universal and free at point of service
A mix of public and private options

questions.text: Climate change is:

options.text: An existential crisis requiring immediate drastic action
A serious problem we need to address

questions.text: Same-sex couples should:

options.text: Have exactly the same rights as heterosexual couples
Have marriage rights with some religious exemptions
Have civil unions but not marriage

questions.text: Trans people should be able to use bathrooms matching their gender identity:
Immigration to this country should be:

options.text: More open with easier paths to citizenship
Maintained at current levels with reforms

questions.text: Systemic racism in this country is:

options.text: A major issue requiring significant reform
A real problem that needs addressing
Overstated but exists in some areas
Largely a thing of the past

questions.text: Police funding and reform:

options.text: We should defund police and invest in community services
Some reforms needed but maintain current funding
Police need more funding and support
Police should have more power and less oversight

questions.text: Gun laws should be:

options.text: Much stricter with fewer guns in circulation
Less strict - more freedom for gun owners
Minimal - the right is nearly absolute

questions.text: Religion's role in government should be:

options.text: None - strict separation of church and state
Moderate - religious values can inform policy
Significant - this is a religious nation
Central - laws should follow religious principles

questions.text: Gender inequality in the workplace:

options.text: Is a major issue requiring proactive policies
Is a real problem that needs addressing
Is mostly explained by choice differences
Is a myth - women have equal opportunity

questions.text: I would describe myself as a feminist:

options.text: Yes, though I don't always use the word
I believe in equality but don't use the label
No - feminism has gone too far

questions.text: The #MeToo movement:

options.text: Was mostly positive with some excesses
Had good intentions but went too far

questions.text: Politically, I would describe myself as:
I vote:
Major events like elections are often manipulated by shadowy groups:

options.text: Strongly disagree - this is conspiracy thinking
Neutral - hard to know what's true
Strongly agree - nothing is as it seems

questions.text: Vaccines are:

options.text: Safe, effective, and essential for public health

questions.text: Social media companies should:

options.text: Actively moderate misinformation and hate speech
Be neutral platforms with minimal intervention
Allow everything - any moderation is censorship

questions.text: The death penalty should be:
Marijuana should be:

options.text: Legal for recreational and medical use

questions.text: Sex work (between consenting adults) should be:

metadata.explanation: Bodily autonomy and sex work values

questions.text: College should be:

options.text: Paid for by those who attend
A privilege for those who can afford it

questions.text: Housing is:

options.text: A human right the government should guarantee
Something the government should help provide
Primarily a market matter with some assistance

questions.text: The minimum wage should be:
Taxes on the wealthy should be:

options.text: Lower - they already pay too much

questions.text: Large corporations have:

options.text: Far too much power and need to be broken up
Too much power and need more regulation
About the right amount of power
Been unfairly targeted - let business succeed

questions.text: People in poverty are usually there because:

options.text: Systemic factors and lack of opportunity
A mix of systemic and personal factors
Both systems and personal choices equally
Their own fault - anyone can succeed

questions.text: Social safety net programs (food stamps, unemployment, etc.):

options.text: Should be expanded and made universal
Are essential and should be strengthened
Are necessary but need some reform
Create dependency and should be reduced
Should be eliminated - charity should handle it

questions.text: US military spending should be:
The US should be more involved in:
When scientists reach consensus on an issue (evolution, climate, vaccines):

options.text: It should inform policy and public understanding
It's probably accurate but open to revision
Scientists can be wrong or biased

questions.text: I could date someone with very different political views:

options.text: No - political values reflect core beliefs
Unlikely - major differences are hard to bridge
Probably - we can agree to disagree

questions.text: 'Traditional values' in society are:

options.text: A mix of good and problematic
The foundation of society that must be protected

questions.text: Traditional gender roles in relationships:

options.text: Are fine if both partners choose them
Are natural and should be maintained

questions.text: 'Toxic masculinity' is:

options.text: A real problem that harms everyone
An issue some men struggle with

questions.text: Certain groups in society have systemic advantages (privilege):

options.text: Strongly agree - this is well documented
Strongly disagree - this concept is divisive

questions.text: 'Cancel culture' is:

options.text: Sometimes justified, sometimes goes too far
Mostly mob justice that's gone too far
A dangerous threat to free speech

questions.text: In a disagreement with my partner, I need resolution:

options.text: Immediately - I can't sleep on conflict
Same day - but I can take a break first
When we're both ready - no timeline
I prefer to avoid conflict altogether

questions.text: I check my phone during quality time with my partner:
My partner spending a weekend with friends without me:

options.text: Is healthy and I'd encourage it
Is unacceptable in a serious relationship

questions.text: How often do you need to communicate with a partner during a typical workday?

options.text: A few check-ins throughout the day
Not necessarily - we'll catch up later
Constantly - I want to know what they're doing
We should be in near-constant contact

questions.text: For major life decisions (job changes, moves, large purchases), couples should:

options.text: Consult each other but respect individual choice
Discuss but one person may have final say
One partner should lead on decisions

questions.text: In relationships, I typically:

options.text: Do a lot of emotional work (planning, remembering, checking in)
Do some but my partner does more
Let my partner handle most of that

questions.text: Household chores should be:

options.text: Split based on who has more time/energy
Split based on who's better at what
Whoever cares more about cleanliness does more

questions.text: I need physical affection (non-sexual touch, cuddling, etc.):
I need verbal expressions of love ('I love you', compliments, etc.):
How much dedicated quality time do you need with a partner weekly?

options.text: We should spend most free time together
Living together is enough quality time
I need a lot of alone time - minimal together

questions.text: Gift-giving in relationships is:

options.text: Very important to me - I love giving and receiving
Uncomfortable - I don't like the pressure

questions.text: When my partner does practical things for me (chores, errands, tasks):

options.text: I feel very loved - this is how I feel cared for
It's nice but not how I feel most loved
I'd rather they express love other ways
I prefer to handle my own things

questions.text: During arguments, I tend to:

options.text: Stay calm and focused on resolution
Get emotional but try to stay constructive
Need to take breaks to cool down
Escalate - I need to be heard

questions.text: After an argument, who usually makes the first move to reconcile?

options.text: I do - I hate leaving things unresolved
My partner should - I won't give in first

questions.text: When my partner gives me constructive criticism, I:

options.text: Appreciate it and try to grow
Listen but need time to process
Get defensive initially but come around
Feel hurt and need reassurance first

questions.text: When I'm venting about a problem, I usually want my partner to:

options.text: Ask what kind of support I need

questions.text: In a relationship, I prefer:

options.text: Merging friend groups - do everything together
Mostly shared social life with some separate friends
Balance of shared and separate social lives
Completely separate - my friends are mine

questions.text: I prefer relationships that move:

options.text: Very fast - when you know, you know
Slowly - I take time to trust
Very slowly - I need lots of time

questions.text: Meeting each other's families should happen:

options.text: Once things are clearly serious (6+ months)

questions.text: Moving in together should happen:

options.text: Maybe never - I value my own space

questions.text: How do you define when a relationship becomes exclusive?

options.text: After dating for a few weeks
It's implied if you're seeing each other regularly

questions.text: How important are relationship labels (girlfriend/boyfriend, partner, etc.)?
Posting about your relationship on social media:

options.text: I love sharing - it's part of my life

questions.text: If I felt jealous in a relationship, I would:

options.text: Examine my feelings and discuss calmly
Tell my partner how I'm feeling
Try to handle it on my own first
Ask my partner to change their behavior
Take action to prevent the situation

questions.text: When my partner and I want different things, I:

options.text: Happily compromise most of the time
Try to find a middle ground
Take turns getting what we want
Usually defer to them to avoid conflict
Usually need to get my way

questions.text: When I'm stressed or upset, I need:

options.text: My partner close by, offering comfort
To talk through it with them
Complete solitude - I'll reach out when ready

questions.text: How often do you express gratitude to your partner for everyday things?

options.text: Rarely - they know I appreciate them

questions.text: How often should couples have 'state of the relationship' conversations?

options.text: Rarely - if it's working, don't fix it

questions.text: In a committed relationship, it's okay to keep some things private from your partner:

options.text: Some privacy is fine but major things should be shared
Yes - I keep a lot private from partners

questions.text: How much should partners share about past relationships?

options.text: Important things - major relationships, lessons learned
Not much - the past is past
Nothing - I don't want to know

questions._section: === ATTACHMENT & EMOTIONAL STYLE (347 questions) - ECR-R Based ===

questions.text: I worry that partners will leave me:
I find it easy to depend on romantic partners:
When my partner is upset with me:

options.text: I can handle it calmly and work on resolution
I want to fix it but stay grounded
I get somewhat anxious until it's resolved
I feel very distressed and need reassurance
I spiral into anxiety and can't function well

questions.text: I am comfortable being emotionally close to partners:
I need a lot of reassurance that my partner loves me:
I prefer not to show a partner how I feel deep down:

options.text: Strongly disagree - I'm an open book
Strongly agree - I keep my feelings private

questions.text: When my partner doesn't want to be close, I worry something is wrong:
I get uncomfortable when a partner wants to be very close:

options.text: Very often - I need my space

questions.text: I sometimes feel like I want to merge completely with someone:
I tell my partner most things about myself:
If I sense a partner is pulling away, I:

options.text: Give them space and trust the relationship
Check in once then give space
Feel anxious but try to stay calm
Become very distressed and need immediate resolution

questions.text: I find it easy to let myself rely on my partner:

options.text: Yes - partnership means relying on each other
No - I rely only on myself

questions.text: I am aware of what I'm feeling most of the time:

options.text: Rarely - I struggle to identify feelings
No - I'm disconnected from my emotions

questions.text: I express my emotions:

options.text: When I feel safe and trust the person

questions.text: Being vulnerable with a partner feels:
It takes me a long time to trust someone:

options.text: Yes - trust must be earned over time
I struggle to fully trust anyone

questions.text: When I'm emotionally overwhelmed, I:

options.text: Reach out to people I trust for support

questions.text: I can calm myself down when I'm upset without needing someone else:
I easily pick up on other people's emotions:

options.text: No - I struggle to read emotions

questions.text: My moods are generally:
I typically go to bed:
My home is typically:
I exercise:
My eating habits are best described as:

options.text: Balanced - I eat what I want in moderation
I don't really track what I eat

questions.text: My dietary preferences/restrictions:
I smoke cigarettes:
I drink alcohol:
I use marijuana:
My feelings about pets:

options.text: I have or want pets - they're family
I like pets and am open to having them
I don't want pets in my home

questions.text: For dogs specifically:

options.text: I have or definitely want a dog
I like dogs and would consider one
I like dogs but don't want to own one
I'm allergic or can't have dogs

questions.text: For cats specifically:

options.text: I have or definitely want a cat
I like cats and would consider one
I like cats but don't want to own one
I'm allergic or can't have cats

questions.text: I typically work:
My work schedule is:

options.text: I work remotely on my own schedule

questions.text: My job requires travel:
How would you describe your approach to money?

options.text: Very frugal - I save most of what I earn
Balanced - I save some and spend some
I spend most of what I earn

questions.text: I currently live:
